description: On July 1st, some higher level schools were opened by the Bhutanese government, as a part of phase one reopening, under the following conditions. Classes X and XII will resume choosing their higher education specialization. Students of classes VII, VIII, IX, and XI will resume after phase one is completed. Classes VI and under will remain online. Technical and vocational education training will start in-person on July 1st. The Royal University of Bhutan will have final year students on campus, while first and second year students are online.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description: From 23 March, 2020, Bhutan closed all its land borders.     Note: Travelers by road from India are major source of footfall into the country.    Prior to this, Bhutan had already banned entry to all foreigners for 14 days from 7 March. This has been extended ever since. This along with the closure of all international borders meant that only travel that was allowed was for repatriation purposes through embassies in respective countries. While there is no explicit formal suspension of flights, all the reports seem to suggest that flights have stopped accepting travellers from around 12 March. Hence listing it as a 4.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 3rd of Arpil, 2020 Ministry of Health has stepped up surveillance systems by testing individuals coming in from high-risk countries right after they land at Paro Airport, irrespective of whether they show symptoms or not.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: There seems to be no change in border policies. date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Borders remain closed. Bhutan authorities imposed a nationwide lockdown on Tuesday, August 11, 2020, following an imported case of the coronavirus disease  COVID-19. All schools, government institutions, offices, and commercial establishments will remain closed until further notice and exams are postponed. The government has advised everyone to stay at home to curb the further spread of the disease. by  Bhutan's borders remain closed, including the international airport at Paro. Repatriation flights for stranded nationals have been authorized. However, returning citizens will have to enter a three-week mandatory quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: "The Ministry of Foreign Affairs would like to inform that an Air Travel Bubble Arrangement has been agreed between the Royal Government of Bhutan and the Government of India on 18th September 2020 to enable flight operations between the two countries till the resumption of normal International flights between the two countries.    Drukair operated its first flight under this arrangement to Bagdogra on 1 October 2020. Hereafter, Drukair will operate 1 flight each to Delhi and Kolkata, and one flight to Bagdogra/Guwahati a week as follows:    1. Paro-Kolkata-Paro on 16th October 2020 (thereafter every Friday)  2. Paro-Delhi-Paro on 19th October 2020 (thereafter every Monday)    Bhutan Airlines also intends to begin operations in the near future.    Travellers will be subject to strict adherence to the mandatory quarantine and other COVID-19 related health protocols put in place by the Royal Government of Bhutan and the Government of India."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On September 28th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced travel requisites when moving from different risk designated areas. People moving from low risk to low risk areas or high risk to high risk areas just need to register with the Royal Bhutan Police. People moving from high risk to low risk areas need to register with their dzongkhag Covid-19 task force and test negative at the end of a seven day quarantine, unless there is an emergency. People moving from low risk to high risk should not travel unless there is an emergency.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On October 8th, the Samdrupjongkhar Dzongkhag Covid-19 task force announced that all gewogs are now a high-risk zone. Movement within the dzongkhag is allowed, but those exiting the areas will have to quarantine for seven days and get a negative PCR test when going to low-risk areas, or just a negative antigen test if going to a different high-risk area.

description: On January 4th, 2021, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced that the country would begin easing its nationwide lock down with the use of zoning. In red zones, Thimphu and Paro, existing restrictions will continue until a later date. In yellow zones, Lhamoidzingkha throm in Dagana, Domkhar and Chamkhar in Bumthang, Phenteykha village in Punakha, Pelela in Wangduephodrang, Kela village in Trongsa and, Katso and Uesu gewogs in Haa, people must use movement cards to travel in their area. Areas other than the ones previously listed will be green zones, where people will be allowed to travel within their district. In seven days, testing will be done to reassess the status of these areas.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On January 4th, 2021, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced that the country would begin easing its nationwide lock down with the use of zoning. In red zones, Thimphu and Paro, existing restrictions will continue until a later date. In yellow zones, Lhamoidzingkha throm in Dagana, Domkhar and Chamkhar in Bumthang, Phenteykha village in Punakha, Pelela in Wangduephodrang, Kela village in Trongsa and, Katso and Uesu gewogs in Haa, people must use movement cards to travel in their area. Areas other than the ones previously listed will be green zones, where people will be allowed to travel within their district. In seven days, testing will be done to reassess the status of these areas. UPDATE: The Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan has announced and enumerated the legal penalties that come with violating the movement card system.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting from 2020 August 11, in Bhutan "Following report of a COVID-19 positive case in Gelephu, who has come in close contact with people in Thimphu, Gelephu and those along the way, the government announces national lockdown starting today.    No movement of people and vehicles within or beyond Dzongkhags will be allowed unless authorised.    Prime Minister will come on BBS live at 7AM to share the details.  The government will share all information with the public as and when it becomes available. Please follow the updates and instructions closely."    "During lockdown ensure you have supplies of essential items that will last for at least 14 days. Those on long term medication should ensure medicines are refilled for at least one month. If not call 6060. Prepare and maintain essential emergency kits such as torchlights, candles, mosquito nets (in southern districts), facemask etc. (...) Only authorized essential service providers and COVID-19 responders identified by the government will be allowed for movement during the lockdown."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 11th 2020, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced a national lockdown following the positive test of a women that visited the capital city. The government will enforce restrictions within and between all districts. All offices, commercial establishments, schools and institutions will be closed. The government will prosecute violations of the lockdown under Section 410 of the Penal Code.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 11th, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced a national lockdown following the positive test of a women that visited the capital city. The government will enforce restrictions within and between all districts. All offices, commercial establishments, schools and institutions will be closed. The government will prosecute violations of the lockdown under Section 410 of the Penal Code. UPDATE: On August 31st, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced the reopening of Bhutan after 21 days of national lockdown. The first phase will take place from September 1st to September 3rd. Phase one of unlocking will allow more relaxation of essential activities, opening of more designated shops and restaurants, while allowing families to walk in the localities.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 11th, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced a national lockdown following the positive test of a women that visited the capital city. The government will enforce restrictions within and between all districts. All offices, commercial establishments, schools and institutions will be closed. The government will prosecute violations of the lockdown under Section 410 of the Penal Code. UPDATE: On September 10th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan announced that the unlocking periods have ended and the country will revert to mostly normal standards that have been in place since March. This will include the inter-district movement of vehicles, with limited capacity for private cars, buses, and taxis. The movement of individuals from low/high risk areas to other low/high risk areas are detailed by the local governments. Businesses can open under guidelines set by the Ministry of Health, including spacing and limited capacity. Schools are opening based on various classes; Classes X and XII will resume from September 14, and Classes IX and XI will also start on-campus school from September 21. Social events are still discouraged and face masks are still mandatory outside of an individual's home.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From August 21, 2020, in Bhutan: "All residents have been instructed to remain within their homes. Only essential workers and individuals engaged in solitary agricultural activities are allowed outside their residences."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Bhutan, After about 41 days, Samdrupjongkhar dzongkhag began the unlocking activities of the dzongkhag in a phase-wise manner (...)"    In the first phase – September 20-22 2020, individuals and families will be allowed to come out from their homes from all the zones. People would be only allowed to walk or cycle all the zones and people would also be allowed to visit the hospital between 10am to noon using their health book.    (...) In the second phase of the unlocking, which starts from September 23-25, movement of public transports including taxis within the dzongkhag would be allowed. However, they are allowed to carry only 50 percent of the full capacity. People can visit the hospital using their private vehicles. Shops such as stationary, mobiles, hardware, aumobile workshops and electronic, among others, would open. All shops can remain open until 7pm.    In the third phase beginning September 26-28, movements of private vehicles within the dzongkhag would be allowed with 50 percent of the permissible passengers. Movement of cars outside the dzongkhag would also be permitted with prior permission from the RBP and Road Safety and Transport Authority
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Starting from 20th December 2020, Thimphu Thromde is under lockdown until further notice. As such, the NCI9TF has decided not to allow any travel out of Thimphu. Further, only emergencies and essential incoming movements into Bhutan will be considered. However, the NC19TF has decided not to allow movement into Thimphu from other Dzongkhags for cremation services.

description: This is to update the public that the lockdown is extended to the super zones, which includes Thimphu throm and peripheral areas of Debsi, RTC area, Gangchey, Nyezergang in the south, Kabesa, Begana and Changtagang in the north. Until further notice, all shops, offices, schools and institutions in the Thimphu Super Zone must remain closed. This is a complete lockdown and there will be no delivery of essentials for now. Depending on the surveillance outcome, the zone wise relaxations and essential supplies will be carried out in the coming days. Toll free line 1010 has been activated to answer to your queries.

description: From January 6, 2021 in Bhutan, Paro and Thimphu districts  Impose stay at home order. Red Zones  Paro and Thimphu districts are red zones. Nonessential activity is suspended. Officials are banning entry and exit in these places, and residents must stay home. Essential services may be limited, and authorities typically deliver essential items to households. Those wishing to travel out of red zones must obtain a movement pass and undergo COVID-19 testing. Such travelers are required to quarantine for seven days at their destination. Officials may declare additional areas as high-risk in the coming days depending on COVID-19 activity; localities near international borders are likely to face similar measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From January 28, 2021 in Bhutan Paro and Thimphu districts  Stay at home order extended. Red Zones  Shaba-Bara of Shaba Gewog, Woochu in Luni Gewog, Khangkhu school premises of Wangchang Gewog in Paro District, and Thimphu District except for the north and south megazones are red zones. Officials have suspended nonessential activity and banned entry and exit in these places; residents must stay home. Essential services may be limited, and authorities typically deliver essential items to households. Those wishing to travel out of red zones must obtain prior permission and undergo COVID-19 testing. Such travelers must typically quarantine for up to seven days at their place of origin and or destination. Officials may declare additional areas such as localities near international borders as high-risk in the coming days, depending on COVID-19 activity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 5th, the Prime Minster's Office of Bhutan announced the beginning of the National Credit Guarantee Scheme (NCGS), which will aim to help ease economic hardship throughout Bhutan by making it easier to access credit.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: The NCGS is a credit program to with the goal of helping individual citizens of Bhutan and helping the country in the following: a) Boosting exports; b) Reducing economic dependency by investing in import substitution-based projects; c) Promoting innovation and technology; and d) Creating jobs to absorb the displaced and unemployed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 2nd, 2021, the Prime Minister's Office of Bhutan announced that the CC19TF will be implementing the Transport Escort Modality starting January 3, 2021. This will include transportation of goods to Thimphu and transit of goods to other Dzongkhags via Thimphu. There will be measures for loading and unloading essential goods such as: vehicle registration, specific times for arrival and unloading, and drivers being required to stay in cars.

description: On March 6, 2020, the Bhutanese government deferred all mass gatherings until further notice. UPDATE: On July 8th, the Ministry of Health of Bhutan stated that they are still discouraging mass gatherings; however, there are instructions for those that are unavoidable. These instructions include, mandatory mask wearing, social distancing of at least one meter, appropriate spacing (preferably in an outside area), mandatory use of the Druk Trace app, hand washing stations, and reporting the event to the local government.
